Post Text: Between 2016 and 2021, Gong grew from a tiny startup with $200k ARR, to a staggering $7.2 billion valuation and half a billion in the bank. Customers routinely told us our sales demos were 2nd to none. Here's 9 lessons I learned about SaaS sales demos I'll never forget:1. Show the most powerful feature FIRST.Most SaaS sellers don't do this. They 'build up' in a 'ramp up' demo.Wrong.Flip it upside down and show the top feature upfront.Let your buyer's head spin (in a good way).Unpack from there.2. Solve exactly.Want an easy way to speed customer decision making?Solve their pain on a 1:1 basis.No more, no less.Don't complicate it by showing all you've got."We can also..." leads to overwhelmed buyers.3. Catalyze a decision.What's the point of a demo?To inform? Educate?Neither. It's to catalyze a decision.What's the 'next' decision your buyer needs to make?Agree on that before the demo.Then, demo in the context of helping them make that decision:"My goal is to get you so FIRED up about what we do that at the end, you're willing to sponsor a meeting with your CMO, or you tell me I missed the mark. Fair?"Catalyze. Don't inform.4. Frame the problem.Summarize the buyer's challenge and impact before the demo.Then validate it:"Based on what you told me, you're going to LOVE this."Let your buyer know they're in the right place.5. Orient them to the screen.Most buyers 3 minutes into SaaS demos:"WTF am I looking at?"Before you click around, explain what they're seeing.The confused mind says 'no.'6. Spend 10s framing the pain a feature solves before showing it.Remember how I said to frame the problem before the demo?Do a mini version of that for each feature you show.What's the pain it solves?Spend 10s summarizing that.THEN the feature will land with ease:"Earlier you said xyz is a headache. Here's how we solve that."7. Tell a customer story after every key feature.Want your buyer to think about your demo for days?Tell a customer story after each click path."Here's how X customer is using that workflow to solve Y pain"People remember stories and forget click paths.8. Ask a question after every key feature.Stop and have a conversation.Here are a few questions to test:- How does that compare to how you solve this today?- To what degree is this resonating so far?- To what extent do you see that solving x pain?- What benefits do you see showing up in your world from that?9. End your demo with "What excited you most about what you saw today?"Transition to discussing next steps.Hope these help.P.S. I've watched over 3,000 Gong calls in my career. Here's a (free) list of 39 questions that sell I've compiled from that: https://go.pclub.io/list

Post Text: As a Cloud Architect, optimizing cloud consumption is a key objective. One challenge with Kubernetes is increasing worker node utilization, which isn't easy to do with kubectl. But with Prometheus and Grafana, we can collect and visualize kube state metrics and node metrics to identify workloads that can be optimized. Recently, we had some workloads with high memory utilization, causing HPA to auto scale the pods to twice the number of replicas and nodes. By allocating additional memory to the pod from idle capacity in the worker node, we were able to increase utilization, reduce the number of worker nodes and cut costs by ~50%. Post Text: I see many guides and examples of using ChatGPT and Claude for CV screening, from AI influencers, HR Tech professionals and startups building on top of LLMs. This is awful. Most guides go like this:-Â Copy the job description-Â Copy 3-5 parsed resumes-Â Write a detailed prompt asking GPT to compare the profiles to the job description.-Â Paste all these in GPT and save tons of time with the results.This is a bit concerning for a few reasons:-Â This is probably illegal in quite a few countries, because LLMs are black boxes and there is no explainability or interpretability as to how the screening results are generated-Â LLMs get worse with extended context, so pasting 10-20 pages of text decreases the quality of response and parts of your prompt will be cut off anyway with GPT3.5.-Â Bias â€“ LLMs are trained on vast datasets that inevitably contain biases present in the source material â€“ this has been shown multiple times in different studies, including recruiting cases.-Â Sharing candidate private data with GPT without their consentWith some advanced implementation, specific problems above can be fixed, like removing personal data or using advanced models to reduce context limitation size.However, the worst problem here is a fundamental lack of understanding of how LLMs work. The absence of real-world awareness or common sense reasoning in LLMs is a critical drawback in screening profiles.While LLMs can process and generate text based on patterns, they do not understand the text in the human sense. Their "understanding" is limited to statistical correlations between words and phrases in their training data. LLMs operate strictly within the scope of the text data on which they have been trained. There is no guarantee that your specific use case is covered with enough qualitative data.Does this mean that LLMs cannot help with candidate screening? Not really. In practical terms, LLMs can assist in screening by automating the identification of relevant qualifications and experiences in CVs that can be used as input further along the screening cycle. They can also be used as natural language interfaces during initial communication with the candidate to verify specific requirements. In recruiting, LLMs should augment peopleâ€™s work, not fully substitute it. They should not be relied upon to make final hiring decisions without human oversight.Â #ai #llms #screening #recruiting #chatgpt #claude
Comment: Using LLMs for CV screening requires caution and human oversight to avoid potential legal and bias issues.
